column38: ASP
column90: does not specify the number of times each type of force was used, ranks by highest type of force used instead. 2018 report states that 4% of the 2,873 uses of force were OC Spray (~115 uses of force) and 1% were ASP strikes (~28 uses of force). 7% of uses of force (~201) were the category including "fist/knee strikes and extended impact weapons" but it does not distinguish how many were extended impact weapon only. Report notes rztended range impact weapons are grouped with fist/knee strikes because "extended impact weapons are not currently used often enough by MPD to warrant their own rank in the hierarchy." As such, extended impact weapon uses are excluded from the less lethal force totals. Taser/ECDs were the highest level of force used 17 times. 2019 report states that 7% of the 2,471 uses of force were OC Spray (~173 uses of force) and 1% were ASP strikes (~25 uses of force). Does not distinguish between fist/knee strikes and extended impact weapons (6% of uses of force), Taser/ECDs were the highest level of force used 13 times. 2020 report states that 6% of the 2,011 uses of force were OC Spray (~121 uses of force) and 1% were ASP strikes (~20 uses of force) and 1% were "Tasers, Police Shield and Canine" deployments (~20 uses of force). Does not distinguish between fist/knee strikes and extended impact weapons (6% of uses of force). 2020 report also includes case-level data on 13 neck restraint incidents from 2018-20. 2021 report states that 9% of the 1,896 uses of force were OC Spray (~171 uses of force) and 1% were ASP strikes and canine bites (~19 uses of force). Does not distinguish between ASP strikes and canine bites. Does not distinguish between fist/knee strikes and extended impact weapons (4% of uses of force = 76), Taser/ECDs were the highest level of force used in less than 1% of uses of force (later in the report it says the agency reviewed 5 cases involving taser usage in 2021). 2021 report also includes case-level data on 1 neck restraint incident in 2021.

column90: UPDATED 5/2023 - removed from 2013-2022 force totals type 22 (pointing firearm), NULL type, and Type 32 from 2022 to ensure consistency across years. "On June 4, 2022, the Department began reporting on a new force type, Type 32 which is defined as any use of force used to overcome resistance of a person during an arrest or detention; or defend oneself or another form combative action by another person and which is not categorized in reporting types 1-31. This type of force includes things such as lifting up and carrying people who had gone limp, pulling people out of cars, pushing people into the back of police cars, etc."

column38: Use of Impact Weapon, Use of Flexible Baton/Beanbag Rounds, Baton, Less Lethal Impact Munitions
column90: use of impact weapon + use of flexible baton/bean bag rounds = impact. Agency reports handcuffing, threats of force, verbal tactics as force, resulting in much larger totals than most agencies. No force used De-escalation technique only, Handcuffing, Threat of Chemical Agent, Threat of Impact Weapon, K-9 locate with warning only, imminent threat of police K-9, threat of taser, Firearm Fired at dog/animal incidents excluded from use of force totals.

column90: Agency indicated they do not have use of force data by force type, only total use of force incidents. Agency: At this time, we are unable to provide more detail. In 2021, we switched to a new Use of Force tracking system. For many reasons and despite a lot of effort put into cleaning up the data, we are unable to rely on any automated counts out of this system. We have begun what amounts to a hand count of all uses of force that will involve reading all of the reports and attempting to properly categorize the uses of force. The results will not be available for some months.

column90: A single Use of Force Incident refers to the specific set of circumstances surrounding an arrest, contact or call for service. A Use of Force Occurrence refers to the actual number of force applications used during a single incident. In 2022, there were 36 Use of Force Incidents involving 38 Use of Force Occurrences by employees, compared to 29 incidents with 34 occurrences in 2021.

column38: Non-lethal weapons, Intermediate weapons
column90: LAW ENFORCEMENT AND CORRECTIONS INCIDENTS INCLUDED. Groups all force involving weapons into Deadly force, Non-lethal weapons and Intermediate weapons. From agency: "For the most part, the non-lethal weapons are devices used by our Special Response Team (SRT) such as flash-bangs and CS gas canisters to a structure or conveyance, but there was one example where a vehicle stop was completed, and the agency vehicle was positioned next to the suspect vehicle to prevent it from entering traffic and the two vehicles made contact. The non-lethal weapons category also included a few traditional intermediate weapons (taser, pepper spray, baton, etc.). Many instances include multiple forms of responses to resistance, so coding can be subjective."

column90: Fewer use of force incidents reported via public records request than to NY state database. This appears to be due to including displays of force in use of force totals reported to the state, yielding 11 total use of force incidents of which 6 were displays only. Displays of force were able to be excluded from total use of force incidents based on individualized data provided directly by agency.

column38: Non-Lethal Weapon

Agency doesn't disaggregate "Non-lethal weapons" category, which includes the use of CEWs (Tasers), K-9, chemical agents, flashlight, etc. "We do not have summary data on sub-categories such as Tasers, K-9, chemical agents, etc. To extract that information would require a review of each report—we don’t provide this kind of research service."

column1: Central CT State University Police Department
column90:
Statewide data reported under Public Act 19-90. No standardized reporting form so there may be more inconsistencies across agencies. " Beginning on July 1, 2022, all police departments in Connecticut are
required to complete a standard use-of-force reporting form." State data includes reporting: 1. When a police officer witnesses another police officer use what the witnessing officer
objectively knows to be unreasonable, excessive, or illegal use of force or is otherwise aware of
such force by another police officer.
2. When a police officer uses physical force that is likely to cause serious physical injury, as defined
in C.G.S. 53a-38
, to another person or the death of another person, including, but not limited to:
a. Striking another person with an open or closed hand, elbow, knee, club, or baton
b. Kicking another person
c. Using pepper spray, or an electronic defense weapon, as defined in C.G.S. 53a-39
, or less
lethal projectile on another person
d. Using a chokehold or other method of restraint applied to the neck area or that
otherwise impedes the ability to breathe or restricts blood circulation to the brain of
another person
e. Discharges a firearm, except during a training exercise or in the course of dispatching an
animal.

objectively knows to be unreasonable, excessive, or illegal use of force or is otherwise aware of
such force by another police officer.
2. When a police officer uses physical force that is likely to cause serious physical injury, as defined
in C.G.S. 53a-38
, to another person or the death of another person, including, but not limited to:
a. Striking another person with an open or closed hand, elbow, knee, club, or baton
b. Kicking another person
c. Using pepper spray, or an electronic defense weapon, as defined in C.G.S. 53a-39
, or less
lethal projectile on another person
d. Using a chokehold or other method of restraint applied to the neck area or that
otherwise impedes the ability to breathe or restricts blood circulation to the brain of
another person
e. Discharges a firearm, except during a training exercise or in the course of dispatching an
animal.

Statewide data reported under Public Act 19-90. No standardized reporting form so there may be more inconsistencies across agencies. " Beginning on July 1, 2022, all police departments in Connecticut are
required to complete a standard use-of-force reporting form." State data includes reporting: 1. When a police officer witnesses another police officer use what the witnessing officer
objectively knows to be unreasonable, excessive, or illegal use of force or is otherwise aware of
such force by another police officer.
2. When a police officer uses physical force that is likely to cause serious physical injury, as defined
in C.G.S. 53a-38
, to another person or the death of another person, including, but not limited to:
a. Striking another person with an open or closed hand, elbow, knee, club, or baton
b. Kicking another person
c. Using pepper spray, or an electronic defense weapon, as defined in C.G.S. 53a-39
, or less
lethal projectile on another person
d. Using a chokehold or other method of restraint applied to the neck area or that
otherwise impedes the ability to breathe or restricts blood circulation to the brain of
another person
e. Discharges a firearm, except during a training exercise or in the course of dispatching an
animal.

Statewide data reported under Public Act 19-90. No standardized reporting form so there may be more inconsistencies across agencies. " Beginning on July 1, 2022, all police departments in Connecticut are
required to complete a standard use-of-force reporting form." State data includes reporting: 1. When a police officer witnesses another police officer use what the witnessing officer
objectively knows to be unreasonable, excessive, or illegal use of force or is otherwise aware of
such force by another police officer.
2. When a police officer uses physical force that is likely to cause serious physical injury, as defined
in C.G.S. 53a-38
, to another person or the death of another person, including, but not limited to:
a. Striking another person with an open or closed hand, elbow, knee, club, or baton
b. Kicking another person
c. Using pepper spray, or an electronic defense weapon, as defined in C.G.S. 53a-39
, or less
lethal projectile on another person
d. Using a chokehold or other method of restraint applied to the neck area or that
otherwise impedes the ability to breathe or restricts blood circulation to the brain of
another person
e. Discharges a firearm, except during a training exercise or in the course of dispatching an
animal.
